titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Marilyn Symmes Collection of Art Exhibition Ephemera
1973-2016 (bulk 1990s-2016)
PR 352
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Alison Barr and Larry Weimer

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2018-05-01T16:15-0400

did.unittitle: Marilyn Symmes collection of art exhibition ephemera

physdesc.extent: in 19 document boxes, one artifact box, and four oversize folders

did.abstract: The collection includes about 2,500 art gallery and museum announcements, posters, brochures, checklists, and other documents obtained by prints and drawings curator Marilyn F. Symmes, mostly from the 1990s-2016. Most of the material relates to modern and contemporary one-artist exhibitions, though two-artist and group exhibitions, including those with themed titles, are also represented. Most of the collection includes materials from New York City art galleries and museums, though institutions elsewhere in the United States and, to a lesser extent, in other countries are also represented.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection includes about 2,500 announcements, guides, brochures, checklists, artwork images, booklet catalogues, and posters from galleries, dealers and museums related to art exhibitions. These materials were either mailed to graphic arts curator Marilyn Symmes or obtained by her when visiting an exhibition. The bulk of the documents/exhibitions date from the 1990s to 2016, when Symmes was working at Cooper Hewitt in New York and later the Zimmerli at Rutgers.

Most of the collection contains documents related to modern and contemporary one-artist exhibitions. These exhibitions primarily included paintings, sculpture, video, photography, prints, drawings, and installations, with some architecture, design, and textiles. Many artists are represented by only one or two documents, while others include multiple documents. Both well-recognized names and less well known artists are found in the collection. The container list attempts to identify at the folder level those artists represented with more extensive or substantive content. Two-artist and group exhibitions, including those with themed titles, are also in the collection. Overall, as Symmes described the content when donating the collection to N-YHS, “The collection presents in microcosm a significant record of modern and contemporary artists whose work was exhibited during this period [1991-2016] primarily in New York City. This collection provides some insight into subjects, issues, materials, styles explored by artists as presented in these exhibitions—thereby reflecting a significant sampling of cultural and social concerns during this time period, as well as commercial interests of the American dealers.”

Most of the collection includes materials from New York City art galleries and museums, though institutions elsewhere in the United States and, to a lesser extent, in other countries are also represented. Among the many galleries represented in the collection are: Alexandre, DC Moore, David Findlay Jr., Deitch Projects, Gemini G.E.L., Grey Art Gallery at N.Y.U., Hirschl & Adler, Gagosian, June Kelly, Mary Boone, Mary Ryan, Matthew Marks, Michael Werner, Marian Goodman, Marlborough, Michael Rosenfeld, Pace, Pace/Wildenstein, Peter Freeman, Sperone Westwater, Sonnabend, Susan Teller, UBU, and David Zwirner. Museums include, among others, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), Whitney, Guggenheim, New Museum, Noguchi, Brooklyn, MassMOCA, Philadelphia, Cooper-Hewitt, Yale, and Zimmerli at Rutgers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: The collection is organized in four series, as presented by the collector/donor:
Series IV. Holiday Greeting Cards, 2006-2014, undated

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Note
bioghist.p: Marilyn F. Symmes, a curator of prints and drawings, received her B.A. in art history from Stanford University and her M.A. in art history and museum practice from the University of Michigan. She began her curatorial career in the 1970s at the Smith College Museum of Art, later moving to the Detroit Institute of Arts and the Toledo Museum of Art.

In 1991, Symmes moved to New York City where she was Curator in charge of the Department of Drawings and Prints at Cooper-Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum until 2002. Symmes worked for the Smithsonian's Archives of American Art as the New York Area Collector from 2003-2004, and then as an independent curator until 2006. In 2006, Symmes was named Director of the Morse Research Center for Graphic Arts and Curator of Prints and Drawings at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University. She held these positions until her retirement in 2015. She continues to remain involved with the art world by doing free-lance curatorial projects.

p.emph: (The above note was based primarily on a biographical note provided by Marilyn Symmes to N-YHS curator Marilyn Kushner.)

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Available by advance appointment only. To schedule an appointment, contact the Print Room Librarian at printroom@nyhistory.org.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)

Permission to reproduce any Print Room holdings through publication must be obtained from: Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 270. Fax: (212) 579-8794.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation Note
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as Marilyn Symmes Collection of Art Exhibition Ephemera, PR 352, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.
Credit line: Gift of Marilyn F. Symmes

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed and inventoried by volunteer Alison Barr, with additional notes provided by archivist Larry Weimer, in April 2018.

controlaccess.subject: Art galleries, Commercial -- New York (State) -- New York
Art museums
Arts publicity -- New York (State) -- New York
Art—Exhibitions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The series includes announcements, guides, brochures, checklists, artwork images, booklet catalogues, and posters from galleries, dealers and museums related to exhibitions centered on the work of one particular artist. The term “catalogue” is used loosely here and refers to a broad range of textual forms intended to provide some level of substantive insight into the content of an exhibition. By the donor’s count, there are approximately 2,000 items in this series.

The container list identifies some, though certainly not all or even most, of the artists represented in a particular folder of documents. Generally, artists were noted if there were several documents related to them or if the documents, even if only one was present, included substantive textual information, such as a checklist, description of artistic purpose, gallery layout, or biographical information. While acknowledging the subjective nature of the effort, an attempt was made to document within the container list where one could find brochure or booklet-type catalogues or other such documents concerning particular exhibitions. Researchers will no doubt find other useful documents within the folders, particularly high quality brochures emphasizing select artwork images or creatively designed gallery mailings, but not all artists and documents could be itemized in this finding aid within the constraints of processing resources.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by artist surname, retaining the order as presented by the collector/donor.

Oversize items: The series includes many oversize items. Those that were originally folded and are only slightly oversize were typically left folded and boxed. Larger pieces were also left folded if it appeared that their design was such that the opening of the piece was integral to interpreting it or appreciating it as an object. Although the items are not especially fragile, care should be taken in unfolding and refolding them; please request assistance from the reference librarian as needed. Several oversize items that were more in the nature of posters were removed from the folders, flattened, and stored separately; all such items are noted individually at the end of the alphabetical container list under the label “oversize.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material from artists, among others, Marina Abramovic, Robert Adams, Yuji Agematsu, and Eric Aho.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material from artists, among others, Laurie Anderson, Benny Andrews, William Anthony, and Stephen Antonakos. Also includes a reflection by Laurie Anderson on her exhibition The Waters Reglitterized (2005). Includes catalogue Stephen Antonakos: Five Decades of Drawing from the Art Gallery at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York and a CD Stephen Antonakos: In his Studio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes materials from artists, among others, Diane Arbus, Cory Arcangel, Siah Armajani, George Ault, and Milton Avery. Includes a Whitney catalogue Cory Arcangel: Pro Tools. Includes a selected chronology of Charles Arnoldi. Includes a folded, poster-sized invitation for Kutlug Ataman's Journey to the Moon (2009). Includes a list of works in Milton Avery's exhibition Milton Avery: Onrushing Waves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes exhibition invitations, book release postcards, and New Year's cards signed by artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes material from artists, among others, Francis Bacon, Trisha Baga, John Baldessari, and Balthus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes material from artists, among others, Will Barnet, Hannelore Baron, and Jennifer Bartlett. Includes an invitation to Will Barnet's Gala Dinner to celebrate his 94th birthday and an invitation to celebrate Will Barnet at 100. Includes an invitation and press release for Jeannette Montgomery Barron on her portrait photograph exhibition. Includes a Jennifer Bartlett's postcard invitation with prices written on the back.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes a brochure from the ESSL Collection with a short biography of the artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes material from artists, among others, Leonard Baskin, Jean-Michel Basquiat, David Bates, Lothar Baumgarten, Romare Bearden, and Sadie Benning. Includes also a catalogue from The Whitney on Sadie Benning's exhibition Play Pause.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes material from artists, among others, Joseph Beuys, Brett Bigbee, Oscar Bluemner, and Erwin Blumenfeld.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes material from artists, among others, Mel Bochner, Christian Boltanski, Lee Bontecou, Fernando Botero, Louise Bourgeois, and Dusty Boynton. Includes the Yale University Art Gallery catalogue and family guide for Mel Bochner: Thought Made Visible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes material from artists, among others, Victor Brauner, Robert Broner, Marcel Broodthaers, Peter Brooke, Moe Brooker, James Brooks, Roger Brown, and Byron Browne. Includes also a Findlay Galleries catalogue, Peter Brooke: The Imagined and The Real.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes material from artists, among others, Charles Burchfield, Rudy Burckhardt, Chris Burden, and James Lee Byars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Material from artists, including, among others, Paul Cadmus, John Cage, Alexander Calder, Sophie Calle, Cornell Capa, Anthony Caro, Mary Cassatt, James Castle, and Maurizio Cattelan. Also includes a 2004 Edmond Casarella brochure from the Susan Teller Gallery with a price list.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Material from artists, including, among others, Marc Chagall, John Chamberlain, Dale Chihuly, Francesco Clemente, and Chuck Close.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials from artists, including, among others, Sue Coe, Dan Colen, James Coleman, James Cornell, Luc Courchesne, and Petah Coyne. Includes prospectus for The Ballad of Lemon and Crow by Glenn Todd, illustrated by Bruce Connor and anonymous artists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials from artists, including, among others, Gregory Crewdson, John Cross, Merce Cunningham, and John Currin. Also includes a 1999 Queens College Art Center exhibition catalogue for John Crawford Sculpture, a 1995 Laurence Miller Gallery catalogue for Ralston Crawford Abstracting the Vernacular, and a 2003 Des Moines Art Center exhibition catalogue for John Currin Works on Paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Includes a 1996 Whitney Museum brochure "Collection in Context: Willem de Kooning's Door Cycle" and a 2006 Matthew Marks Gallery checklist for Willem's exhibition Sketchbook.

The scroll is signed and dated by Ruppersberg. Access restriction: The object can be unrolled only with the assistance of the conservator; advance arrangements are required.

Also includes a sheet of slides with images of works by Phyllis Seltzer and her assistant Zoya Trofimova (1993-2001).

scopecontent.p: Includes material for artist Cy Twombly, including a MoMA 1995 exhibition guide for Cy Twombly: A Retrospective.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists, including, among others, Lee Ufan and Tom Uttech. Also includes a prospectus for "A Day in the Bleachers" by Arnold Hano and illustrated by Mark Ulriksen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists, including, among others, Manolo Valdes, James Valerio, Sara VanDerBeek, Francesco Vezzoli, and Bill Viola. Also includes a Whitney Museum 2010 exhibition guide for Sara VanDerBeek, a Museum of Contemporary Art, Cleveland, 2014 interview with Sara VanDerBeek, a Gagosian Gallery, Beverly Hills, and a Guggenheim Museum 2002 exhibition guide for Bill Viola: Going Forth by Day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists, including, among others, Edmund De Waal, John Walker, Richard Walker, Darren Waterston, and Carleton E. Watkins. Also includes a Kraushaar Gallery 2005 exhibition pamphlet Lee Walton: Baseball Drawings, a Philadelphia Museum of Art exhibition guide Marcel Wanders: Daydreams, and a Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art 2014 exhibition pamphlet Darren Waterston: Uncertain Beauty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artist Andy Warhol, including a DIA Center for the Arts 1994 exhibition guide for Andy Warhol: The Last Supper Paintings, a prospectus for a limited edition portfolio of photographs of Andy Warhol taken by William John Kennedy in 1964, and a MoMA 2003 exhibition guide for Andy Warhol: Screen Tests.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists, including, among others, William Wegman, Lawrence Weiner, Robert Weingarten, and Ai WeiWei. Also includes a Whitney Museum 2007 exhibition guide for Lawrence Weiner: As Far As The Eye Can See, a Kentler International Drawing Space 2006 exhibition pamphlet for Monika Weiss: Limen 2, and a Zimmerli Art Museum 2012 exhibition guide for Rachel Perry Welty: 24/7.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists, Neil Welliver, including a Alexandre Gallery 2004 exhibition catalogue for Neil Welliver: Oil Studies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists, including, among others, Franz West, Minor White, and Rachel Whiteread. Also includes a Hall Art Foundation 2014 exhibition guide for Franz West: Les Pommes d'Adam, and a Clark Art Institute 1998 exhibition guide for Charles White: Progression of the American Negro.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists, including, among others, Charmion Von Wiegand, Kehinde Wiley, Christopher Williams, Philemona Williamson, Fred Wilson, and Jane Wilson. Also includes a Brooklyn Museum 2015 media preview for Kehinde Wiley: A New Republic, a MoMA 2014 exhibition guide for Christopher Williams: The Production Line of Happiness, and a Ubu Gallery 2006 publication for Stanislaw Ignacy Witkiewicz: Drawings from the 1930s, and a 2013 mailing from Michael Rosenfeld Gallery that included, with Wiegand. a large lapel pin for the exhibition American Abstraction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artist Terry Winters, including a Two Palms Press 2002 publication for Terry Winters: Shadowgraphs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists, including, among others, Jonas Wood, Betty Woodman, Francesca Woodman, Christopher Wool, Alexi Worth, Frank Lloyd Wright, and Richard Wright. Also includes a New Museum of Contemporary Art 1998 exhibition guide for Sweet Oblivion: The Urban Landscape of Martin Wong, a Marian Goodman Gallery 2012 publication for Francesca Woodman: The Blueprints, and a National Building Museum 1997 exhibition guide for Frank Lloyd Wright: American Spirit Alive in Japan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists Liu Xiaodong, Qiu Xiaofei, and Xiaoze Xie.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists, Mao Yan, Catherine Yass, Liu Ye, David Zink Yi, Aaron Young, Jack Youngerman, Lisa Yuskavage, and Kimiko Yoshida.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists Abbie Zabar, Robert Zandvliet, Zao Wou-Ki, Eva Zeisel, Alexander Zhitomirsky, Elyn Zimmerman, Nola Zirin, Andrea Zittel, Marilyn Zorach, Gilberto Zorio, Kevin Zucker, and Unica Zurn. Also includes a New Museum 2006 exhibition guide for Andrea Zittel: Critical Space, and 2012 press releases from the Andrea Rosen Gallery for Andrea Zittel's Fluid Panel State.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes advertisement poster for artist's proofs of Donald Baechler's Red Coral (2004); Gabrielle Basilico (2004) at MIT galleries; Dan Colen Secrets and Cymbals, Smoke and Scissors (My Friend Dash's Wall in the Future) (2006) at Deitch Projects; Dan Colen Blowin' in the Wind (2012) at Gagosian; Gregory Crewdson Sanctuary (2011) at Gagosian Rome; newspaper format guide for Ann Hamilton the event of a thread (2012) at Park Avenue Armory; Tim Hawkinson (2009) at Pace/Wildenstein; Jasper Johns Catenary (2005) at Matthew Marks; Joe Bradley Krasdale (2016) at Gagosian; Roy Lichtenstein Nudes (1994) at Leo Castelli; Agnes Martin The '80s: Grey Paintings (2011) at 534 West 25th Street; Steven Parrino (2007) at Gagosian; A.R. Penck Constructions (2004) at Michael Werner; Charles Seliger New Paintings (2006) at Michael Rosenfeld; Richard Serra To Whom It May Concern (1995) at Matthew Marks; Richard Serra Venice Notebook Series (2002) at Gemini; Christer Stromholm (2016) at Pace/MacGill; Thomas Struth (2015) at the Met; Robert Therrien (2008) at Gagosian; prospectus (2000) for book Phrase Book by Rick Moody, illustrated by Fred Tomaselli; Andy Warhol From the Sonnabend Collection (2009) at Gagosian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes John Baldasarre (2005), Noses & Ears (2006), Sediment (Part 2) (2010), Double Play (2012), and Movie Scripts/Art (no year) at Marian Goodman; Glenn Brown (2014) at Gagosian; Aaron Curry mmnktlplkt (2010) at Michael Werner; Jim Dine (2004) at Pace Prints; Peter Doig New Paintings (2009) at Michael Werner; Felix Gonzalez-Torres (2004) at Max Fraenkel; Al Held (2004) at Robert Miller; Christopher Wool (2006) at Gagosian Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes Lothar Baumgarten Imago Mundi (2004) at Marian Goodman; Dan Colen Miracle Paintings (2014) at Gagosian; Anselm Kiefer hortus philosophorum (2009) and Next Year in Jerusalem (2010) at Gagosian; Ryan McGinness Figure Drawings (2014) at Pace Prints; Philip Pearlstein (2004) at Robert Miller; Giuseppe Penone (2012) at Gagosian; Robert Rauschenberg Works on Metal (2014) at Gagosian; Edward Ruscha Anamorphic Paintings (1995) at Leo Castelli; Richard Serra (2009) at Gagosian; Francesco Vezzoli The Gore Vidal Trilogy (2006); Adrian Villar Rojas Two Suns (2015) at Marian Goodman; Lawrence Weiner En Route (2005), At the Level of the Sea (2009), and Gyroscopically Speaking (2011) at Marian Goodman.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by the surname of the first artist used in the publicity material, retaining the order as presented by the collector/donor. One oversize item was flattened and stored separately, and is noted at the end of the container list.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The series includes announcements, guides, brochures, checklists, artwork images, and posters from galleries, dealers and museums related to exhibitions centered on the work of two artists. There are approximately 55 documents in the series. The container list includes reference to all the exhibitions represented in the series, identifying them by artist surnames in the form “artist 1/artist 2.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists Adamo/Castle, Albers/Albers, Albers/Judd, Allora/Calzadilla, Anderson/Low, Andrews/Israel, Apfelbaum/Giorno, Arbus/Nolan, Bailey/Hirst, Bearden/Lewis, Becher/Sander, Bertozzi/Casoni, Beuys/Le Va, Blume/Blume, Boetti/Bouabre, Bond/Simon, Byington/Nakadate, Calder/Prouve, Cardiff/Bures, Cattelan/Fontana, Chamberlain/Francis, and Chamberlain/Prouve.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists Donovan/Mangold, Dubuffet/Basquiat, Eilshemius/Thompson, Fekete/Schiel, Fischli/Weiss, Flavin/Albers, Friedlander/Bonnard, Giacometti/Bacon, Giacometti/Klein, Graham/Vogt, Guston/Johns, Inez/Vinoodh, Israel/Ellis, Jacquette/Burckhardt, and Johns/Nauman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material for artists Lawrence/Knight, Le Corbusier/Jeanneret, Lundeberg/Feitelson, McCartney/McCartney, Nauman/Rothenberg, Oldenburg/Van Bruggen, Picasso/Braque, Rich/Grossman, Richter/Pardo, Robbins/Becher, Sagmeister/Walsh, Sargent/Bingham, Sayler/Morris, Shinzo/Fukuhara, Von Graevenitz/Morellet, Weiner/Young, Wilson/Ryman, Winokur/Burko, Witkin/Witkin, and Wood/Kusaka.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes only one poster: Halley/Mendini at Mary Boone Gallery.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in alphabetical order, by institution name. There was no original order to the documents in this series so the arrangement was determined by the processing archivist. A few oversize items were flattened and stored separately, and they are noted at the end of the container list.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The series includes announcements, guides, brochures, checklists, artwork images, and posters from galleries, dealers and museums related to exhibitions that included work by more than two artists. Generally, these exhibitions emphasized topics, genre, or other themes, rather than highlighting particular artists. Unlike the first two series, which identified artist names, the container list here identifies all the galleries or museums that presented exhibitions represented in the series. (Although the degree of overlap is not known, the institutions identified here are representative of those found in the first two series.) By the donor’s count, there are approximately 400 items in the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes material from multiple artists shows at the following museums and galleries: Alexandre Gallery, Aljira Center, American Academy of Arts and Letters, American Folk Art Museum, Anthony Grant, The Art Students League of New York, and Axa Gallery.
